snippet.title: Visit Rome - What to Know Before You Visit Rome, Italy
snippet.description:
Roma, The Eternal City. If you are heading to Rome there are quite a few things you should know before you go. Here we go over all the basic tourist information and necessities that a traveler needs to get the most out of their visit to Rome. The airports, the public transportation, safety issues, accommodation in Rome, what to eat and Roman specialties, and so much more. This is made for first time visitors to Rome so they can get the most out of their visit.
Filmed in Rome, Italy
Copyright Mark Wolters 2018

Support Us: https://www.patreon.com/woltersworld

comments.textDisplay:
I was in Rome for 14 days in May (and yes you need that much time to do it right); some more advice...

First - Plan! Plan! Plan! and when you're done, plan some more! Rome is a daunting city, but if done right, you will LOVE it.
Do not just show up and expect to see everything. Book ahead! Seriously, treat visiting the major sites like booking a Broadway play during Christmas season. All museums and sites have online booking options (except for the Vatican Museums, their online booking portal was down...bummer!). Some sites are so popular and space limited, you MUST book ahead (Borghese Gallery and the Domus Aurea especially).

Second - Don't go in summer (mid June - early September). I know vacation times may make this unavoidable, but seriously, Rome is hell in summer. The Italians leave, the tourists flood in...crowds are thick, the heat is beyond insane, prices skyrocket and many neighborhood eateries are on summer holiday. I was there in August 2003 and wow, it was miserable!

Third - Take your time! If you only have a 4 days, then focus your trip on a theme: Ancient Rome, Catholic Rome, foodie Rome, etc...if you try to conquer everything in a few days you will be exhausted, bewildered and you probably won't have many fond memories. If you have 2 weeks, just do Rome and save Florence/Venice for another trip; you'll thank me. And if you're concerned you will have too much time, there are wonderful day trips to do...I recommend Orvieto (1 hour by train north from Rome), which is one of Italy's best hill towns!

Lastly - Get out the center of the city. Rome gets "real" outside the main areas. Go to the Salario neighborhood (one of Europe's grandest urban areas...kind of like a colorful Paris) Testaccio for some good food and art scenes, and Esquilino (where the Rome meets the world: Chinese fashion entrepreneurs rub shoulders with Lebanese hooka bars and Bangladeshi children play cricket in the park).

Rome is awesome, plan well and enjoy!

comments.textDisplay: just a little tip from a Roman follower: there's a local train from Fiumicino Airport to Tuscolana station (which is located in the south-eastern part of Rome, just 2 metro stops from San Giovanni). That's a lot cheaper than the 13 euros Leonardo Express (it costs 8 euros per person per trip) and the journey takes just a few more minutes.
comments.textOriginal: just a little tip from a Roman follower: there's a local train from Fiumicino Airport to Tuscolana station (which is located in the south-eastern part of Rome, just 2 metro stops from San Giovanni). comments.textDisplay:
Plan ahead! Go through the big sites in the first few days, THEN relax and soak in the back roads of Italian lifestyle. I recommend doing a day for Ancient Rome (Colosseum, Forum, Pantheon) and then a day for Catholic Rome (St. Peter’s, Vatican Museums, other major churches).

If you’re looking for a couple things that not everyone does, I recommend the Capuchin Monks Crypt, the Parco degli Aquedotti, and the basilica of St. Paul’s Outside the Walls (if you’re catholic or just interested in it, try to visit mass at one of the major basilicas when there’s a cardinal performing mass. It’s a worthwhile experience!)

As for neighborhoods, Trastevere is now really touristy but still fun. I also like Esquilino (there’s a huge indoor market there) as well as Testaccio.

The most “overrated” sites are the Trevi Fountain and the Spanish Steps. They’re both cool and worth checking out, but they’re so crowded because of how tight quarters there are in those areas. I think a walk through Villa Borghese is a great way to spend some time in the city as well (think of it like Rome’s version of Central Park)

Tourist traps are everywhere as far as restaurants, pickpockets, and people shoving selfie sticks in your face. Just be smart in the areas near a big site. You can find good food at reasonable prices just a block off the main drags.

Day trip outside of Rome? You can do Florence in a day if you’re just wanting to see the must-visit stuff, or Pisa is up there too. Naples/Pompeii is south and is a perfect day trip too. I’d recommend at minimum maybe like 5 days to experience Rome, but stay longer if you can!

comments.textDisplay:
The pickpockets are not Italians. They are gypsies from Romania and other Eastern European Block countries (i.e. Albania mostly). You will see gangs of young girls on the Metro, beware!.
Never take your passport with you, leave it in a hotel safe. Make a photocopy and carry that on you.
I grew up in Rome, and every time I go back, it's worse and worse. Pickpockets, street vendors, etc.
It isn't the city it used to be in the 80s and 90s. Luckily Salvini is doing something about the scum.

I liked Rome a lot, but it didn't dislodge my favorite European cities: Paris, Prague, Tbilisi, Lyon and now Palermo.(I loved Palermo!) Rome seemed so dedicated to tourism that I couldn't crack it, the way I long ago did for Paris. Yes I saw the big sites. (Trevi Fountain should be renamed Selfie Fountain these days. But the Pantheon was incredible.) My favorite aspect of Rome was hunting down Bernini statues in out of the way churches. That brought things to life for me in much less touristic environments. And oh my the pizza I found while doing that! Walking! Yes. So much that I was glad to take an excruciatingly slow bus back to the Vatican area where my inexpensive hotel was located. The slow bus ride gave me a much needed break.I wish I had seen this then! Obviously this is the beginning of a new series. More please!

comments.textDisplay: We went to Rome last year in August and made it our home base in April for visits to Florence and Venice.  I can offer two additional tips. One, do not skip the opportunity to go inside a church and I mean any church. Trust me, just go in. It's almost always free (some might charge a few euro) and you will see art worthy of the best museums. Secondly, if you go in the second half of August you should know that many, many Romans take vacation the second half of August. It wasn't a huge burden for us but we did miss out on some local restaurants that we wanted to visit because the owners were on vacation. The other thing to consider if you go in August and you visit the coast is it will be ccroowwdded. I mean it. Everyone is on vacation. Everyone goes to the coast. Again, not a huge deal for us as we hadn't planned a day at the beach but we did visit Amalfi and it was hard getting around.

comments.textDisplay: I loved Rome. As far as walking, be prepared to go up and down tons of hills. The city is very hilly. All of the food I had there was very good and very cheap. A starter, main course, dessert, liter of house wine and bottle of sparkling water was cheaper than a main course and beer at Applebee's. I think I had carbonara 5 times. Lastly with pickpockets, watch out for organized groups. I saw a group of young pickpockets near termini. One of them had a mini pig. If you stopped to look at it, the others would circle behind you and try to get into your bag. They were professionals. Overall, Rome is my favorite city in Europe. Great video. All the info in here is accurate.

replies.textDisplay:
If you have an EU country sim card, you can use it in Italy as you would in your home country; if you need a sim card, as a tourist I would recommend you to buy an Iliad sim card, because most of the other carriers tend to tie you to longer contracts which you will never use and that have fees to be terminated. The cost is €10 for the sim card and €8 a month for 50GB in 4G, unlimited call time and sms, with calls to foreign telephone numbers included. You can find their booths at almost any shopping mall in Rome and the purchase system is fully automated and digital, almost no paperwork required. You can look at the details at their website iliad.it
Other carriers are TIM, Vodafone, WIND, H3G, Postemobile and Coopvoce.

comments.textDisplay: I really would emphasize the pickpockets. It is a problem and always be on high alert. Also watch when going to your hotel with your luggage. If you have an amount of luggage that is challenging for you to handle and a person offers to help you it is most likely a scam. Be weary when trusting people. Also make sure you validate your ticket for the train they do check and will fine you. Other than that Rome is a great city and don't be discouraged about visiting over this just be aware of it and you will be fine.

comments.textDisplay:
I was in Rome last week, I had the most miserable time. There were just too many people and it was so humid. I went nine years ago the week before Christmas and it was so much better, hardly any tourists, we got to see everything without having to fight hoards of people and ticket touts and there was a lovely festive atmosphere.

My top tip would be don't use Uber, its much more expensive then normal taxis and watch out for taxi's trying to take advantage on trips to and from the airport, the pricing structure is clearly written on the side of taxi's but some will try to add to the cost because of 'luggage or traffic.' One taxi driver tried to charge us 190 euro instead of 48 because of 'traffic.' Clearly tell them no and move on, plenty of taxi's available, no need to be ripped off!
